No my Lord, but wiſe men wonder at it: you hauing ſo buried your wiſedome heretofore in Tauerns, and Vaultinghouſes,
that the world could neuer diſcouer you to be capable of Honour.

sp.speaker: D'ol.
sp.p: As though Achilles could hide himſelfe vnder a Womans clothes: was he not diſcouered at firſt? This Honor is like a Woman, or a Crocadile (chuſe you whether) it flies them that follow it; and followes them that flie it: For my ſelfe, how euer my worth, for the time kept his bedd; yet did I euer prophecie to my ſelfe that it would riſe, before the Sun-ſet of my dayes: I did euer dreame, that this head was borne to beare a breadth, this ſhoulder to ſupport a State, this face to looke bigg, this bodie to beare a preſence, theſe feete were borne to be reuellers, and theſe Calues were borne to be Courtiers: In a word, I was borne Noble, and I will die Noblie: neither ſhall my Nobilitie periſh with death; after ages ſhall re • ounde the memorie thereof, while the Sunne ſets in the Eaſt, or the Moone in the Weſt.

sp.speaker: Pac.
sp.p: Or the Seuen Starres in the North.

sp.speaker: D'ol.
sp.p: The Siege of Bullaine ſhall be no more a landmarke for Times: Agencourt Battaile, S. Iames his Fielde, the loſſe of Calice, & the winning of Cales, ſhal grow out of vſe: Men ſhal reckon their yeares, Women their mariages, from the day of our Ambaſſage: As, I was borne, or married two, three, or foure yeares before the great Ambaſſage. Farmers ſhall count their Leaſes from this day, Gentlemen their Morgages from this day: Saint Dennis ſhall be rac't out of the Kallender, and the day of our Enſtalment enterd in redd letters: And as St. Ualentines day is fortunate to chooſe Louers, St. Lukes to chooſe Husbandes; So ſhall this day be to the chooſing of Lordes: It shall be a Critticall day, a day of Note: In that day it shall be good to quarrell, but not to ſight: They that Marrie on that day, shall not repent; marie the morrow after perhappes they may: It shall be holſome to beat a Sergeant on that day: Hee that eates Garlicke on that morning, shall be a rancke Knaue till night.

sp.speaker: Diq.
sp.p: What a day will this be, if it hold?

sp.speaker: D'ol.
sp.p:
Hold▪ S'foote it shall hold, and shall be helde ſacred to immortalitie: let all the Chroniclers, Ballet makers, and
Almanackmunger • , do what they dare.

sp.speaker: Rhod.
sp.p: S'foote (my Lord) al's daſht, your voyage is ouerthrowne.

sp.speaker: D'ol.
sp.p: What ayles the franticke Tro?

sp.speaker: Rhod.
sp.p: The Lady is entoombde, that was the Subiect of your Ambaſſage: and your Ambaſſage is beraid.

sp.speaker: Pac.
sp.p: Dido is dead, and wrapt in lead.

sp.speaker: Di.
sp.p: O heauy herſe!

sp.speaker: Pac.
sp.p: Your Lordſhips honor muſt waite vpon her.

sp.speaker: Dig.
sp.p: O ſcur • y verſe! Your Lordſhip's welcome home: pray let's walke your horſe my Lord.

sp.speaker: D'ol.
sp.p: A prettie gullery. Why my little wits, doe you beleeue this to be true?

sp.speaker: Pac.
sp.p: For my part my Lord, I am of opinion you are guld.

sp.speaker: Dig.
sp.p: And I am of opinion that I am partly guiltie of the ſame.

sp.speaker: Muge.
sp.p: Where's this Lord foole here? S'light you haue made a prettie peece of ſeruice an't: raiſed vp all the countrey in gold lace and feathers; and now with your long ſtay, there's no employment for them.

sp.speaker: D'ol.
sp.p: Good ſtill.

sp.speaker: Mug.
sp.p: S'light I euer tooke thee to be a hammer of the right feather: but I durſt haue layed my life, no man could euer haue cramd ſuch a Gudgeon as this downe the throate of thee: To create thee a Chriſtmas Lord, and make thee laughter for the whole Court: I am aſhamde of my ſelfe that euer I chuſde ſuch a Groſſeblocke to whet my wits on.

sp.speaker: D'ol.
sp.p: Good wityfaith.

I know all this is but a gullery now: But ſince you haue preſumde to go thus farre with me, come what can come to the State, ſincke or ſwimme, Ile be no more a father to it, nor the Duke; nor for the world wade one halfe ſteppe further in the action.

sp.speaker: Pac.
sp.p: But now your Lordſhip is gone, what ſhall become of your followers?

sp.speaker: D'ol.
sp.p: Followers? let them follow the Court as I haue done: there let them raiſe their fortunes: if not, they know the way to the pettie Brokers, there let them ſhift and hang. Exit cum ſui • .

sp.speaker: Rhod.
sp.p: Here we may ſtrike the Plaudite to our Play, my Lord foole's gone: all our audience will forſake vs.

sp.speaker: Mug.
sp.p: Page, after, and call him againe.

sp.speaker: Rho.
sp.p: Let him go: Ile take vp ſome other foole for the Duke to employ: euery Ordinary affoords fooles enow: and didſt not ſee a paire of Gallants ſit not far hence like a couple of Boughpots to make the roome ſmell?

sp.speaker: Mug.
sp.p: Yes, they are gone: But what of them?

sp.speaker: Rhod.
sp.p: Ile preſſe them to the Court: or if neede • e, our Muſe is not ſo barren, but ſhe is able to deuiſe one tricke or other to retire D'oliue to Court againe.

sp.speaker: Mug.
sp.p: Indeed thou toldſt me how gloriouſly he apprehended the fauour of a great Lady i • h Preſence, whoſe hart (he ſaid) ſtood a tipto in her eye to looke at him.

sp.speaker: Rhod.
sp.p: Tis well remembred.

sp.speaker: Mug.
sp.p: O, a Loue-letter from that Ladie would retriue him as ſure as death.

sp.speaker: Rhod.
sp.p: It would of mine honor: Weele faine one from her inſtantly: Page, fetch pen and inke here.

sp.speaker: Mug.
sp.p: Now do you & your Muſe engender: my barren skonce ſhall prompt ſomething.

sp.speaker: Rhod.
sp.p: Soft then: The Lady I • ronime, who I ſaid viewed him ſo in the Preſence, is the Venus that muſt enamour him: Weele go no further for that. But in what likeneſſe muſt he come to the Court to her now? As a Lord he may not: in any other ſhape he will not.

sp.speaker: Mug.
sp.p: Then let him come in his owne ſhape like a gull.

sp.speaker: Rhod.
sp.p: Well, diſguiſde he ſhall be: That ſhall be his miſtriſſes direction: this ſhall be my Helicon: and from this quiuer will I draw the ſhaft that ſhall wound him.

sp.speaker: Mug.
sp.p: Come on: how wilt thou begin?

sp.speaker: Rhod.
sp.p: Faith thus: Dearely Beloued.

sp.speaker: Mug.
sp.p: Ware ho, that's prophane.

sp.speaker: Rhod.
sp.p: Go to then: Diuine D'oliue: I am ſure that's not prophane.

sp.speaker: Mug.
sp.p: Well, forward:

sp.speaker: Rhod.
sp.p: I ſee in the powre of thy beauties.

sp.speaker: Mug.
sp.p: Breake of your period, and ſay, Twas with a ſigh.

sp.speaker: Rhod.
sp.p: Content: here's a full pricke ſtands for a teare too.

sp.speaker: Mug.
sp.p: So, now take my braine.

sp.speaker: Rhod.
sp.p: Poure it on.

sp.speaker: Mug.
sp.p: I talke like a foole, but alas thou art wiſe and ſilent.

sp.speaker: Rhod.
sp.p: Excellent: And the more wiſe, the more ſilent.

sp.speaker: Mug.
sp.p: That's ſomething common.

sp.speaker: Rhod.
sp.p: So ſhould his miſtris be.

sp.speaker: Mug.
sp.p: That's true indeed: Who breakes way next?

sp.speaker: Rhod.
sp.p: That will I ſir: But alas, why art not thou noble, that thou mightſt match me in Blood?

sp.speaker: Mug.
sp.p: Ile anſwer that for her.

sp.speaker: Rhod.
sp.p: Come on.

sp.speaker: Mug.
sp.p: But thou art noble, though not by birth, yet by creation.

sp.speaker: Rhod.
sp.p: Thats not amiſſe: forth now: Thy wit proues thee to be a Lord, thy preſence ſhowes it: O that word Preſence, has coſt me deare.

sp.speaker: Mug.
sp.p: Well ſaid, becauſe ſhe ſaw him ith Preſence.

sp.speaker: Rhod.
sp.p: O do but ſay thou lou'ſt me.

sp.speaker: Mug.
sp.p: Soft, there's too many OOs.

sp.speaker: Rhod.
sp.p: Not a whit: O's but the next doore to P. And his miſtris may vſe her O with with modeſtie: or if thou wilt, Ile ſtop it with another brachiſh teare.

sp.speaker: Mug.
sp.p: No, no, let it runne on.

sp.speaker: Rhod.
sp.p: O do but ſay thou lou'ſt me, and yet do not neither, and yet do.

sp.speaker: Mug.
sp.p: Well ſaid, let that laſt ſtand, let him doe in any caſe: now ſay thus, do not appeare at Court.

sp.speaker: Rhod.
sp.p: So.

sp.speaker: Mug.
sp.p: At leaſt in my companie.

sp.speaker: Rhod.
sp.p: Well.

sp.speaker: Mug.
sp.p: At leſt before folkes.

sp.speaker: Rhod.
sp.p: Why ſo?

sp.speaker: Mug.
sp.p: For the flame will breake forth.

sp.speaker: Rhod.
sp.p: Go on: thou doeſt well.

sp.speaker: Mug.
sp.p: Where there is fire ith harth:

sp.speaker: Rhod.
sp.p: What then?

sp.speaker: Mug.
sp.p: There will be ſmoke ith chimn • y.

sp.speaker: Rhod.
sp.p: Forth.

sp.speaker: Mug.
sp.p: Warme, but burne▪ me not: theres reaſon in all things.

sp.speaker: Rhod.
sp.p: Well ſaid, now do • I vie it: Come to my chamber betwixt two and three.

sp.speaker: Mug.
sp.p: A very good number.

sp.speaker: Rho.
sp.p: But walk not vnder my window: if thou doeſt, come diſguiſde: in any caſe we are not thy tu • t taffe • a • loke: if thou doeſt, thou killeſt me.

sp.speaker: Mug.
sp.p: Well ſaid, now to the L'envoye.

sp.speaker: Rhod.
sp.p: Thine, if I were worth ought; and yet ſuch, as it skils not whoſe I am if I be thine; Ieronime: Now for a fit Pandar to tranſport i • , and haue at him.

lg.l: COme my good Lord, now will I trie my Braine,
If it can forge another golden chaine,
To draw the poore Recluſe, my honord miſtris
From her darke Cell, and ſuperſtitious vow.
Loft haue heard there is a kind of ••• re
To fright a lingring Feuer from a man
By an imaginous feare, which may be true,
For one heate (all know) doth driue out another,
One paſſion doth expell another ſtill,
And therefore I will vſe a fainde deui • e
To kindle • urie in her frozen Breaſt,
That rage may fire out griefe, and ſo reſtore her
To her moſt ſociable ſelfe againe.
Iuno Lucina fer opem,
And eaſe my labouring houſe of ſuch a care.
Marke but my Midwifery: the day is now
Some three houres old, and now her night begins:
Stand cloſe my Lord, if ſhe and her ſad meany
Be toward ſleepe, or ſleeping, I will wake them
With orderly alarmes; Page? Boy? ſiſter?
All toong-tied? all aſleepe? page? ſiſter?
Alas Vandome, do not diſturbe their reſt
For pittie ſake, tis yong night yet with them.
My Lord, your onely way to deale with women
And Parrets, is to keepe them waking ſtill.
Page? who's aboue? are you all dead here?

sp.speaker: Dig.
sp.p: S'light is hell broke looſe? who's there?
sp.stage: He looks out with a light.

sp.speaker: Vand.
sp.p: A friend.

lg.l: Then know this Caſtle is the houſe of wo,
Here harbor none but two diſtreſſed Ladies
Condemn'd to darkneſſe, and this is their iayle,
And I the Giant ſet to guard the ſame:
My name is Dildo.

sp.speaker: Vand.
sp.p: Sirra leaue your rogerie, and hearken to me: what Page, I ſay.

sp.speaker: Dig.
sp.p: Tempt not diſaſters: take thy life: Be gone.

sp.speaker: Uau.
sp.p: An excellent villani • .

sp.speaker: Vand.
sp.p: Sirra? I haue buſineſſe of waight to impart to your Ladie.

sp.speaker: Dig.
sp.p: If your buſineſſe be of waight, let it waite till the after noone, for by that time my Ladie will be deliuered of her firſt ſleepe: Be gone, for feare of watery meteors.

sp.speaker: Vand.
sp.p: Go to ſir, leaue your villany, and diſpatch this newes to your Ladie.

sp.speaker: Dig.
sp.p: Is your buſineſſe from your ſelfe, or from ſome body beſides?

sp.speaker: Vand.
sp.p: From no body beſides my ſelfe.

sp.speaker: Dig.
sp.p: Very good; then Ile tel her, here's one beſides himſelfe has buſineſſe to her from no body.

sp.speaker: Vau.
sp.p: A perfect yong hempſtring.

sp.speaker: Van.
sp.p: Peace leaſt he ouer heare you.

sp.speaker: Dig.
sp.p: You are not the Conſtable ſir, are you?

sp.speaker: Vand.
sp.p: Will you diſpatch ſir? you know me well enough, I am Vandome.

sp.speaker: Eury.
sp.p: Whats the matter? who's there? Brother Vandome.

sp.speaker: Vand.
sp.p: Siſter?

sp.speaker: Eury.
sp.p: What tempeſt driues you hither at ſuch an hower?

sp.speaker: Vand.
sp.p: VVhy I hope you are not going to bed, I ſee you are not yet vnready: if euer you will deſerue my loue, let it be now, by calling forth my miſtris, I haue newes for her, that touch her nearely.

sp.speaker: Eur.
sp.p: VVhat is • good brother?

sp.speaker: Van.
sp.p: The worſt ofils: would any tongue but mine had bene the meſſenger.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: VVhats that ſeruant?

sp.speaker: Van.
sp.p: O Miſtris come downe with all ſpeed poſſible, and leaue that mournfull cell of yours, Ile ſhew you another place worthy of your mourning.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: Speake man, my heart is armed with a mourning habit of ſuch proofe, that there is none greater without it, to pierce it.

sp.speaker: Vand.
sp.p: If you pleaſe to come downe, Ile impart what I know: if not, Ile leaue you.

lg.l: VVhy ſtand you ſo at gaze ſiſter? go downe to him.
Stay bother, ſhe comes to you.
Twill take I doubt not, though her ſelſe be ice,
Theres one with her all fire, and to her ſpirit
I muſt apply my counterfeit deuice:
Stand cloſe my Lord.

sp.speaker: Uau.
sp.p: I warrant you, proceed.

lg.l: Come ſilly miſtris, where's your worthy Lord?
I know you know not, but too well I know.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: Now heauen graunt all be well.

lg.l: How can it be?
VVhile you poore Turtle ſit and mourne at home,
Mewd in your cage, your mate he • lies abroade,
O heauens who would haue thought him ſuch a man?

sp.speaker: Eury.
sp.p: Why what man brother? I beleeue my ſpeeches will proue true of him.

sp.speaker: Uand.
sp.p:
To wrong ſuch a beautle, to prophane ſuch vertue,
and to proue diſloyall.

sp.speaker: Eury.
sp.p: Diſloyall? nay nero gilde him ore with fine termes, Brother, he is a filthy Lord, and euer was, I did euer ſay ſo, I neuer knew any good ath haire, I do but wonder how you made ſhift to loue him, or what you ſaw in him to entertaine but ſo much as a peece of a good thought on him.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: Good ſiſter forbeare.

sp.speaker: Eury.
sp.p: Tuſh ſiſter, b • d me not forbeare: a woman may beare, and beare, and be neuer the better thought on neither: I would you had neuer ſeene the eyes of him, for I know he neuer lou'd you in's life.

lg.l: You wrong him ſiſter, I am ſure he lou'd me
As I lou'd him, and happie I had bene
Had I then dide, and ſhund this hapleſſe life.

sp.speaker: Eury.
sp.p: Nay let him die, and all ſuch as as he is, he lay a catterwalling not long ſince: O if it had bene the will of heauen, what a deare bleſſing had the world had in his ridda • ce?

lg.l: But had the lecher none to ſingle out
Forobiect of his light laſciuious blood,
But my poore coſin that attends the Dutcheſſe, Lady Ieronime?

sp.speaker: Eury.
sp.p: What, that blaberlipt blouſe?

lg.l: Nay no blouſe, ſiſter, though I muſt confeſſe
She comes farre ſhort of your perfection.

sp.speaker: Eury.
sp.p: Yes by my troth, if ſhe were your coſin a thouſand times, ſhees but a ſallow freckld face peece when ſhe is at the beſt.

lg.l: Yet ſpare my coſin, ſiſter, for my ſake,
She merits milder cenſure at your hands.
And euer held your worth in nobleſt termes.

sp.speaker: Eury.
sp.p: Faith the Gentlewoman is a ſweete Gentlewoman of her ſelfe, I muſt needs giue her her due.

sp.speaker: Vand.

lg.l: But for my Lord your husband, honor'd miſtris,
He made your beauties and your vertues too,
But foyles to grace my coſins, had you ſeene
His amorous letters,

sp.p: But my coſin preſently will tell you all, for ſhe reiects his ſute, yet I aduiſde her to make a ſhew ſhe did not. But point to meet him when you might ſurpriſe him, and this is iuſt the houre.

sp.speaker: Eury.
sp.p: Gods my life ſiſter, looſe not this aduantage, it wil be a good Trumpe to lay in his way vpon any quarrell: Come, you ſhall got S'bodie will you ſuffer him to diſgrace you in this ſort? diſpraiſe your beautie? And I do not think too, but he has bin as bold with your Honor, which aboue all earthly things ſhould be deareſt to a woman.

sp.speaker: Uand.
sp.p: Next to her Beautie.

sp.speaker: Eury.
sp.p: True, next to her beautie: and I doe not thinke ſiſter, but hee deuiſeth ſlaunders againſt you, euen in that high kinde.

sp.speaker: Vand.
sp.p: Infinite, infinite.

sp.speaker: Eury.
sp.p: And I beleeue I take part with her too: would I knew that yfaith.

sp.speaker: Vand.
sp.p: Make your account, your ſhare's as deepe as hers: when you ſee my coſin, ſheele tell you all: weele to her preſently.

sp.speaker: Eury.
sp.p: Has ſhe told you, ſhe would tell vs?

sp.speaker: Vand.
sp.p: Aſſurde me, on her oath.

sp.speaker: Eury.
sp.p: S'light I would but know what he can ſaye I pray you brother tell me.

sp.speaker: Vand.
sp.p: To what end? twill but ſtirre your patience.

sp.speaker: Eury.
sp.p: No I proteſt: when I know my cariage to be ſuch, as no ſtaine can obſcure, his ſlaunders ſhall neuer moue me, yet would I faine know what he faines.

sp.speaker: Uan.
sp.p: It fits not me to play the goſſips part • w •• l to my coſin, ſheele relate all.

sp.speaker: Eury.
sp.p: S'light what can ſhe ſay? pray let's haue a taſte an't onward.

sp.speaker: Vand.
sp.p: What can he not ſay, who being drunke with luſt, and ſurfetting with deſire of change, regards not what he ſayes: and briefly I will tell you thus much now; Let my melancholy Lady (ſayes he) hold on this courſe till ſhe waſte her ſelfe, and conſume my reuenew in Tapers, yet this is certaine, that as long as ſhe has that ſiſter of hers at her elbow.

sp.speaker: Eury.
sp.p: Me? why me? I bid defiance to his foule throate.

sp.speaker: Vaum.
sp.p: Hold there Vandome, now it begins to take.

sp.speaker: Eury.
sp.p: What can his yellow iealouſie ſurmiſe againſt me? if you loue me, let me heare it: I proteſt it ſhall not moue me.

sp.speaker: Vand.
sp.p: Marry forſooth, you are the ſhooing horne, he ſayes, to draw on, to draw on ſiſter.

sp.speaker: Eury.
sp.p: The ſhooing horne with a vengeance? what's his meaning in that?

sp.speaker: Vand.
sp.p: Nay I haue done, my coſin ſhall tell the reſt: come ſhal we go?

sp.speaker: Eury.
sp.p: Go? by heauen you bid me to a banquet: ſiſter, reſolue your ſelfe, for you ſhall go; looſe no more time, for you ſhall abroade on my life: his licorice chaps are walking by this time: but for heauens ſweete hope what meanes he by that ſhooing horne? As I liue it ſhall not moue me.

sp.speaker: Vand.
sp.p: Tell me but this, did you euer breake betwixt my miſtris and your ſiſter here, and a certaine Lord ith Court?

sp.speaker: Eury.
sp.p: How? breake?

sp.speaker: Vand.
sp.p: Go to, you vnderſtand me: haue not you a Petrarch in Italian?

sp.speaker: Eury.
sp.p: Petrarch? yes, what of that?

sp.speaker: Van.
sp.p: Well, he ſayes you can your good, you may be waiting womā to any dame in Europe: that Petrarch does good offices.

sp.speaker: Eury.
sp.p: Marry hang him, good offices? S foot how vnderſtands he that?

sp.speaker: Vand.
sp.p: As when any Lady is in priuate courtſhip with this or that gallant, your Petrarch helpes to entertaine time: you vnderſtand his meaning?

sp.speaker: Eury.
sp.p: Siſter if you reſolue to go, ſo it is: for by heauen your ſtay ſhall be no barre to me, Ile go, that's infallible; it had bene as good he had ſlandered the diuell: ſhooing horne? O that I were a man for's ſake.

sp.speaker: Vand.
sp.p: But to abuſe your perſon and your beautie too: a grace wherein this part of the world is happie: but I ſhall offend too much.

sp.speaker: Eury.
sp.p: Not me, it ſhall neuer moue me.

sp.speaker: Uand.
sp.p: But to ſay, ye had a dull eye, a ſharpe noſe (the viſible markes of a ſhrow) a drie hand, which is a ſigne of a bad liuer, as he ſaid you were▪ being toward a husband too: this was intolerable.

sp.speaker: Uaum.
sp.p: This ſtrikes it vp to the head.

sp.speaker: Uand.
sp.p:
Indeed he ſaid you dreſt your head in a pretie ſtrange
faſhion • but you would dreſſe your husbands head in a far ſtranger; meaning the Count of ſaint Anne I thinke.

sp.speaker: Eury.
sp.p: Gods precious, did he touch mine honor with him?

sp.speaker: Vand.
sp.p: Faith nothing but that he weares blacke, and ſayes tis his miſtris colours: and yet he proteſts that in his eye your face ſhewes well enough by candle light, for the Count neuer ſaw it otherwiſe, vnleſſe twere vnder a maske, which indeed he ſayes becomes you aboue all things.

lg.l: Come Page, go along with me, Ile ſtay for no body:
Tis at your coſins chamber, is it not?

sp.speaker: Uand.
sp.p: Marry is it, there you ſhall find him at it.

sp.speaker: Eury.
sp.p: That's enough: let my ſiſter go waſte his reuenew in tapers, twill be her owne another day.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: Good ſiſter, ſeruant, if euer there were any loue or reſpect to me in you both.

sp.speaker: Eury.
sp.p: Siſter? there is no loue, nor reſpect, nor any coniuration, ſhall ſtay me: and yet by my part in heauen, Ile not be moued a whit with him: you may retire your ſelfe to your old coll, and there waſte your eyes in teares, your heart in ſighes, Ile away certaine.

sp.speaker: Uan.
sp.p: But ſoft, let's agree firſt what courſe we ſhal take when we take him.

sp.speaker: Eury.
sp.p: Marry euen raiſe the ſtreetes on him, and bring him forth with a flocke of boyes about him, to whoote at him.

sp.speaker: Vand.
sp.p: No, that were too great a diſhonor: Ile put him out on's paine preſently.

sp.speaker: Pag.
sp.p: Nay good ſir ſpare his life, cut of the offending part, and ſaue the Count.

lg.l: Is there no remedie? muſt I breake my vow?
Stay Ile abroad, though with another aime
Not to procure, but to preuent his ſhame.
Go Page, march on, you know my coſins chamber,
My company may wrong you, I will croſſe
The nearer way, and ſet the houſe afore you:
But ſiſter ſee you be not mou'd for Gods ſake.
Not I by heauen: Come ſiſter, be not moued,
But if you ſpare him, may heauen nere ſpare you.

sp.speaker: Vand.
sp.p: So now the ſolemne votary is reuin'd.

lg.l: Pray heauen you haue not gone a ſtep too farre,
And raiſde more ſprites, then you can coniure downe.

sp.speaker: Vand.

lg.l: No my Lord, no, t'Herculean labor's paſt,
The vow is broke, which was the end we ſweat for,
The reconcilement will meet of it ſelfe:
Come lets to Court, and watch the Ladies chamber,
Where they are gone with hopefull ſpleene to ſee you.

sp.stage: Enter Roderique, Mugeron, D'oliue in diſguiſe towards the Ladies chamber.

sp.speaker: Rhod.
sp.p: See Mugeron, our counterfait letter hath taken: who's yonder think'ſt?

sp.speaker: Mug.
sp.p: Tis not Doliue:

lg.l: Ift be not he, I am ſure hee's not farre off:
Thoſe be his treſſels that ſupport the motion.

sp.speaker: Mug.
sp.p: Tis he by heauen, wrapt in his careleſſe cloke: See the Duke enters▪ Let him enioy the benefite of the inchanted Ring, and ſtand a while inuiſible: at our beſt oportunitie weele diſcouer him to the Duke.
sp.stage: Enter Duke, Dutcheſſe, Saint Anne, Vaumont, Uandome, to them Digue, whiſpering Vandome in the care, and speakes as on the other ſide.

sp.speaker: Dig.
sp.p: Monſieur Vandome, yonders no Lord to be found: my Ladie ſtayes at hand and craues your ſpeech.

sp.speaker: Vand.
sp.p: Tell her ſhe miſtook the place, and conduct her hither: How will ſhe looke when ſhe findes her expectation mockt now?

sp.speaker: Vaum.
sp.p: What's that, Uandome?

sp.speaker: Uand.
sp.p: Your wife and ſiſter are comming hither, hoping to take you and my coſin together.

sp.speaker: Uau.
sp.p: Alas, how ſhall we appeaſe them, when they ſee themſelues ſo deluded?

sp.speaker: Van.
sp.p: Let me alone, and ſtand you off my Lord:

Madame, y'are welcome to the Court: doe you ſee your Lord
yonder? I haue made him happie by training you forth: In a word, all I ſaid was but a traine to draw you from your vow: Nay, there's no going backe: Come forward and keepe your temper. Siſter, cloud not you your forhead: yonder's a Sunne will cleare your beauties I am ſure. Now you ſee the ſhooing-horne is expounded: all was but a ſhooing-horne to draw you hither: now ſhew your ſelues women, and ſay nothing.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.p: Let him alone awhile Uandome: who's there? what whiſper you?

lg.l: Y'aue done? come forward:
See here my Lord, my honorable miſtris,
And her faire ſiſter, whom your Highneſſe knowes
Could neuer be importunde from their vowes
By prayer, or th'earneſt • utes of any friends,
Now hearing falſe report that your faire Dutcheſſe
Was dangerouſly ſicke, to viſit her
Did that which no friend elſe could winne her to,
And brake her long kept vow with her repaire.
Madam you do me an exceeding honor,
In ſhewing this true kindneſſe to my Dutcheſſe,
Which ſhe with all her kindneſſe will require.
Now my good Lord, the motion you haue made, To S. An.
With ſuch kind importunitie by your ſelfe,
And ſeconded with all perſwaſions
On my poore part, for mariage of this Ladie,
Her ſelfe now comes to tell you ſhe embraces,
And (with that promiſe made me) I preſent her.

sp.speaker: Eury.
sp.p: Siſter, we muſt forgiue him.

lg.l: Matchleſſe Ladie,
Your beauties and your vertues haue archieu'd
An action that I thought impoſſible,
For all the ſweete attractions of your ſex,
In your conditions, ſo to life reſembling
The grace and faſhion of my other wife:
You haue re ••• 'd her to my louing thoughts,
And all the honors I haue done to her,
Shall be continude (with increaſe) to you.

sp.speaker: Mug.
sp.p: Now let's diſcouer our Ambaſſador, my Lord.

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.p: Do ſo.

sp.speaker: Mug.
sp.p: My Lord? my Lord Ambaſſador?

sp.speaker: D'ol.
sp.p: My Lord foole, am I not?

sp.speaker: Mug.
sp.p: Go to, you are he: you cannot • loke your Lordſhippe from our knowledge.

sp.speaker: Rho.
sp.p: Come come: could Achilles hide himſelfe vnder a womans clothes? Greatneſſe will ſhine through clouds of any diſguiſe.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.p: Who's that Rhoderique?

sp.speaker: Rho.
sp.p: Monſieur D'oliue, my Lord, ſt • lne hither diſguiſde, with what minde we know not.

sp.speaker: Mug.
sp.p: Neuer ſtriue to be gone ſir: my Lord, his habite expounds his heart: twere good he were ſearcht.

sp.speaker: D'oliue.
sp.p: Well rookes wel, Ile be no longer a blocke to whet your dull wits on: My Lord, my Lord, you wrong not your ſelfe onely, but your whole ſtate, to ſuffer ſuch v • cers as theſe to gather head in your Court▪ neuer looke to haue any action ſort to your honor, when you ſuffer ſuch earewigs to creepe into your eares thus.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.p: What's the matter Rhoderique?

sp.speaker: Rho.
sp.p: Alas my Lord, only the lightneſſe of his braine, becauſe his hopes are loſt.

sp.speaker: Mug.
sp.p: For our parts, we haue bene truſtie and ſecret to him in the whole manage of his ambaſſage.

sp.speaker: D'ol.
sp.p: Truſtie? a plague on you both, there's as much truſt in a common whore as in one of you▪ and as for ſecrecy, there's no more in you then in a profeſt Scriuener.

sp.speaker: Vand.
sp.p: Why a Scriuener, Monſiour D'oliue?

sp.speaker: D'ol.
sp.p: Marry ſir a man cannot truſt him with borrowing ſo much as poore ſortie ſhillings, but he will haue it Knowne to all men by theſe preſents.

sp.speaker: Vand.
sp.p: Thats true indeed, but you employed theſe gentlemen very ſafely.

sp.speaker: D'oliue.
sp.p:
Employed? I mary ſir, they were the men that firſt kindled this humor of employment in me: a pox of employment I ſay: it has coſt me, but what it has coſt me, it skils not: they haue thruſt vpon me a crew of thredbare, vnbutton'd fellowes,
to be my followers: Taylers, Frippers, Brokers, caſheerd Clarks, Petrifoggers, and I know not who I: S'light I thinke they haue ſwept all the bowling allies ith citie for them: and a crew of theſe, ra • t like old ragges out of dunghils by candle light, haue they preſented to me in very good faſhion, to be gentlemen of my traine, and ſolde them hope of raiſing their fortunes by me: A plague on that phraſe, Raiſing of fortunes, it has vndone more men when ten dicing houſes? Raiſe their fortunes with a vengeance? And a man will play the foole and be a Lord, or be a foole and play the Lord, he ſhall be ſure to want no followers, ſo there be hope to raiſe their fortunes. A burning feuer light on you, and all ſuch followers. S'foote they ſay followers▪ are but ſhadowes, that follow their Lords no longer then the ſunſhines on them: but I finde it not ſo: the ſunne is ſet vpon my employment, and yet I cannot ſhake off my ſhadowes; my followers grow to my heeles like kibes, I cannot ſtir out of doores for am. And your grace haue any employment for followers, pray entertaine my companie: theyle ſpend their bloud in your ſeruice, for they haue little elſe to ſpend, you may ſoone raiſe their fortunes.

lg.l: Well Monſieur D'oliue, your forwardneſſe
In this intended ſeruice, ſhall well know
What acceptation it hath wonne it ſelfe
In our kind thoughts: nor let this ſodaine change
Diſcourage the deſignements you haue laid
For our States good: reſerue your ſelfe I pray,
Till fitter times: meane time will I ſecure you
From all your followers: follow vs to Court.
And good my Lords, and you my honor'd Ladies,
Be all made happie in the worthy knowledge
Of this our worthy friend Monſieur D'oliue.

sp.speaker: Omnes.
sp.p: Good Monſieur D'oliue.
